subHints.title: Factorial Formula
subHints.text: Take a look at the denominator, if we keep applying the L’Hôpital’s Rule $$infinitely$$, we will obtain the general form of factorial: $$x k \left(k-1\right) \neq k \left(k-1\right) \neq k!$$

subHints.title: Explanation
subHints.text: No matter how many time we apply the L’Hôpital’s Rule, the limit will always have the form $$\frac{\infty}{\infty}$$. The derivative of $$e^x$$ on the numerator will always be the same. Meanwhile, as we apply the L’Hôpital’s Rule successively, the function in the denominator will behave: $$k x^{k-1}$$, $$k \left(k-1\right) x^{k-2}$$, k*(k-1)*(k-2)*x**(k-3),...,k!x,k!
